docs.snippet: ONCE more Paraguay and Bolivia are flushed with the fever of war. More than a century ago the seeds of today's quar- rel were sown and for more than fifty years the two countries have been at the sword's point. Their quarrel is over the division of...
docs.lead_paragraph: ONCE more Paraguay and Bolivia are flushed with the fever of war. More than a century ago the seeds of today's quar- rel were sown and for more than fifty years the two countries have been at the sword's point. Their quarrel is over the division of the Gran Chaco Boreal -- an immense area of swamps, plains and dense jungle, the frontiers of which touch Brazil, Paraguay, Argentina and Bolivia.

headline.main: PARAGUAY AND BOLIVIA AT ODDS FIFTY YEARS OVER GRAN CHACO; In the Present Territorial Dispute, Bolivia Is Seeking to Secure an Outlet to the Atlantic by Way of the Paraguay River

docs.snippet: To the Editor of The New York Times: Having just returned from an unofficial and quiet observation of the British Empire Imperial Economic Conference at Ottawa, may I point out a few facts which have not been emphasized in the news dispatches?

headline.main: PAN-AMERICAN SOLIDARITY.; Close Trade Cooperation Here Seen as Outcome of Ottawa Meeting.

docs.snippet: LONG BEACH, Cal., Aug. 9. -- Bobby Pearce of Australia, world's single sculls champion, successfully stood off the challenge of Bill Miller of Philadelphia today as the Olympic rowing regatta program was launched in the Marine Stadium before a crowd...
docs.lead_paragraph: LONG BEACH, Cal., Aug. 9. -- Bobby Pearce of Australia, world's single sculls champion, successfully stood off the challenge of Bill Miller of Philadelphia today as the Olympic rowing regatta program was launched in the Marine Stadium before a crowd of 10,000 spectators.

headline.main: MILLER, U.S. OARSMAN, BEATEN BY PEARCE; Launches Sturdy Threat, but World's Champion Prevails With Powerful Finish. SOUTHWOOD, BRITAIN, WINS Also Enters Final in Singles by Defeating Douglas as 10,000 Look On. FOUR NATIONS TRIUMPH Major Honors Go to Poland, England, Italy, Australia in Various Rowing Contests.

byline.original: By ALLISON DANZIG.Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

headline.main: THE CHACO DISPUTE.; Immediate Arbitration and Prompt Settlement Urged to End Trouble in South America.

docs.snippet: To the Editor of The New York Times: Bolivia and Paraguay are again at odds over the Chaco territory. This is the second time in four years that the Chaco controversy has brought the two South American nations to the verge of war. In December, 1928,...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor of The New York Times: Bolivia and Paraguay are again at odds over the Chaco territory. This is the second time in four years that the Chaco controversy has brought the two South American nations to the verge of war. In December, 1928, Paraguayan forces took by surprise the Bolivian outpost Vanguardia, precisely when the first Pan-American conference on arbitration was convening in Washington.

docs.snippet: LONG BEACH, Cal., Aug. 11 -- The powerful crews of Great Britain and Canada, beaten respectively by Italy and the United States yesterday, came back strongly in the repechage today to qualify for the final round of the Olympic eightoared championship...
docs.lead_paragraph: LONG BEACH, Cal., Aug. 11 -- The powerful crews of Great Britain and Canada, beaten respectively by Italy and the United States yesterday, came back strongly in the repechage today to qualify for the final round of the Olympic eightoared championship in which they will row on Saturday with the two afore-mentioned shells.

headline.main: NEW ZEALAND EIGHT BEATEN BY BRITISH; Cambridge Crew Wins Right to Enter Olyhipic Final by 3/4- Length Triumph. CANADIANS SCORE EASILY Advance by 2-Length Victory Over Germany, With Japanese Eight Third. 2 GERMAN FOURS QUALIFY Entry in Double Sculls Also Reaches Title Round -- Miller, U.S., Douglas, Uruguay, Gain.

byline.original: By ALLISON DANZIG.Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: LONG BEACH, Cal., Aug. 12. -- Turning back the greatest challenge he has met since he won the championship at Amsterdam in 1928, Bobby Pearce of Australia retained his Olympic single sculls crown today in a thrilling race which produced a magnificent...
docs.lead_paragraph: LONG BEACH, Cal., Aug. 12. -- Turning back the greatest challenge he has met since he won the championship at Amsterdam in 1928, Bobby Pearce of Australia retained his Olympic single sculls crown today in a thrilling race which produced a magnificent bid for victory by Bill Miller of the United States.

headline.main: Pearce of Australia Keeps Sculls Title; U.S. Wins Two Crowns in Olympic Swim; OLYMPIC SCULLS WON BY PEARCE

byline.original: By ALLISON DANZIG.Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES.By ALLISON DANZIG

docs.snippet: To the Editor of The New York Times: In your edition of Aug. 11, under the heading "The Chaco Dispute," you published a letter signed by Abbot Maginnis, former United States Minister to Bolivia, and also an anonymous letter from G.N. These...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor of The New York Times: In your edition of Aug. 11, under the heading "The Chaco Dispute," you published a letter signed by Abbot Maginnis, former United States Minister to Bolivia, and also an anonymous letter from G.N. These communications are so erroneous and misleading that they cannot be allowed to pass without correction.

headline.main: THE CHACO DISPUTE.; Paraguayan Charge d'Affaires States His Country's Side.

docs.snippet: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 16. -- A government communique today says that troops under Colonel Playsant in the southern sector began attacking Xiririca this morning.
docs.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 16. -- A government communique today says that troops under Colonel Playsant in the southern sector began attacking Xiririca this morning.
